semantic_title: Single Code Assignment When Same Code Describes Multiple Adverse Reactions or Effects
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > e. Adverse Effects, Poisoning, Underdosing and Toxic Effects > 3. If the same code would describe the causative agent

content.full_text: If the same code would describe the causative agent for more than one adverse reaction, poisoning, toxic effect or underdosing, assign the code only once. (Evidence: pg no: 82, L39-L40)
content.summary: Instruction to assign a drug or substance code only once when the same causative agent is responsible for multiple different adverse reactions or effects (Evidence: pg no: 82, L39-L40)
key_concepts: Single code assignment for same causative agent (Evidence: pg no: 82, L39-L40)
Multiple adverse reactions from one agent (Evidence: pg no: 82, L39)
Avoid duplicate coding of same substance (Evidence: pg no: 82, L40)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If the same code would describe the causative agent for more than one adverse reaction, assign the code only once (Evidence: pg no: 82, L39-L40)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a single drug or substance causes multiple different adverse effects, the causative agent code should be assigned only once, even though multiple manifestations may be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 82, L39-L40)
common_applications: One substance with multiple toxic effects

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify all adverse reactions/effects present
Step 3: Check if same agent causes multiple effects
Step 5: Assign causative agent code only once
